title-group.article-title: Two new species and one new record of Parakiefferiella Thienemann, 1936 from China (Diptera, Chironomidae)

aff.addr-line: College of Life Science, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China
Tianjin Key Laboratory of Animal and Plant Resistance, Tianjin Normal University, Tianjin, 300387, China

fn.p: Academic editor: F. L. da Silva

permissions.copyright-statement: Wenbin Liu, Bingjiao Sun, Chuncai Yan, Chao Song, Xinhua Wang

license.license-p: This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License (CC BY 4.0), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original author and source are credited.

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.p: Two new species of the genus Parakiefferiella Thienemann, 1936 (Parakiefferiella fasciata Liu & Wang, sp. n. and Parakiefferiella liupanensis Liu & Wang, sp. n.) are described as adult males from China. Parakiefferiella tamatriangulata Sasa is recorded from China for the first time. A key to the known adult males of Parakiefferiella from China is presented. The generic diagnosis of male Parakiefferiella given by Cranston et al. (1989) is emended.

sec.title: Citation
sec.p: Liu W, Sun B, Yan C, Song C, Wang X (2015) Two new species and one new record of Parakiefferiella Thienemann, 1936 from China (Diptera, Chironomidae). ZooKeys 545: 139â€“148. doi: 10.3897/zookeys.545.6000

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The genus Parakiefferiella was erected by Thienemann in 1936, with Parakiefferiella coronata (Edwards, 1929) as type species. According to Cranston et al. (1989), it can be separated from other orthoclad genera by the following combination of characters: eyes bare, without dorsomedial extension; acrostichals absent but scutum with median tuft of microtrichia, sometimes on hump; wing membrane without setae, with fine punctation; squama bare; transverse sternapodeme gently curved, with developed oral projections. Virga strongly developed. Gonostylus with more or less well pronounced curve or bend and slight or absent crista dorsalis. Larval stages of the genus are found in both running and standing waters. Adults fly during spring and summer, rarely in large numbers.

The genus is probably quite speciose. Tuiskunen (1986) described four new species and redescribed eight species from Fennoscandian region. Moubayed (1991, 1994) and recently Moubayed-Breil and Langton (2004) described three additional species: Parakiefferiella pyrenaica Moubayed, 1991 (France); Parakiefferiella wuelkeri Moubayed, 1994 (western Europe and north Africa); Parakiefferiella normandiana Moubayed-Breil & Langton, 2004 (France, Germany and England). According to the catalog of Japanese Orthocladiinae (Yamamoto 2004), ten valid species were record in Japan. Nine species were reported in the Russian Far East by Makarchenko and Makarchenko (2010). To date, 44 species of the genus have been recorded worldwide, of which 33 are Palaearctic, seven are Nearctic, three are Oriental, four are Neotropical and four are Afrotropical (Ashe and Oâ€™Connor 2012; Ree, Nam and Jeong 2012).

So far, three species of the genus (Parakiefferiella bathophila (Kieffer, 1912), Parakiefferiella coronata (Edwards, 1929) and Parakiefferiella tipuliformis (Tokunaga, 1940)) were recorded in China (Wang 2000). The species Parakiefferiella tipuliformis (Tokunaga, 1940) from Taiwan province previously placed in Spaniotoma (Smittia) by Tokunaga (1940) was transferred to Parakiefferiella by Sasa and Kikuchi (1995). The species diagnostic characters fit the genus Parakiefferiella. Moreover, Parakiefferiella coronata (Edwards, 1929) was recorded just as larval stage (Wang 2000).
Based on specimens from China, two new species are described in this paper, and a key to the species of Parakiefferiella in China is provided.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
Morphology and terminology follow SÃ¦ther (1980). The material examined was slide-mounted following the procedures outlined by SÃ¦ther (1969). Measurements are given as the range followed by the mean. Color is described as observed in specimen preserved in alcohol. The specimens examined in this study are deposited in the
College of Life Sciences, Nankai University, China (BDN).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Emended diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Based on the material examined and references, the generic diagnosis of male Parakiefferiella (Cranston et al. 1989) must be emended as follows: antenna with 12â€“13 or occasionally with five (Parakiefferiella gynocera (Edwards, 1937)) or ten (Parakiefferiella fasciata Liu & Wang, sp. n. and Parakiefferiella liupanensis Liu & Wang, sp. n.) flagellomeres; wing anal lobe weakly to moderately developed (Parakiefferiella bathophila (Kieffer, 1912)); R and R1 with few setae, occasionally all veins bare (Parakiefferiella fasciata Liu & Wang, sp. n. and Parakiefferiella liupanensis Liu & Wang, sp. n.); anal point with 2â€“8 basal setae, sometimes bare (Parakiefferiella fasciata Liu & Wang, sp. n.).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type material.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Holotype: â™‚ (BDN. No.1165), China, Shandong Province, Yantai City, Kunyu Mountain, 37Â°30'10"N, 121Â°23'40"E, 24.viii.1987, sweeping net, Wang XH. The specimens were sealed with Canada balsam on slides. Paratypes: 3 â™‚â™‚, data as holotype.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: The adult male can be distinguished from known species of the genus by the following combination of characters: anal point lacking keel, very broad at base, rounded apically, without basal setae; virga consisting of four spines; antenna with ten flagellomeres, AR 0.47â€“0.50; tergites III and VIII dark brown, others tergites pale yellow; HR 1.98â€“2.06; HV 2.65â€“3.00.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Description.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Male imago (n = 4). Total length 1.04â€“1.09, 1.07 mm. Wing length 0.71â€“0.72, 0.71 mm. Total length/wing length 1.45â€“1.56, 1.47. Wing length/length of profemur 3.24â€“3.29, 3.26.
Coloration. Head brown. Thorax brown with dark spot. Tergites (Fig. 4) III and VIII dark brown, others tergites pale yellow.

caption.p: Parakiefferiella fasciata Liu & Wang, sp. n., male. 1 wing 2 antenna 3 thorax 4 abdomen tergites coloration 5 hypopygium (dorsal view) 6 inferior; 7 hypopygium (ventral view).

tp:treatment-sec.p: Head. Antenna (Fig. 2) with ten flagellomeres. AR 0.47â€“0.50, 0.49. Ultimate flagellomere 137â€“144, 140 Î¼m long. Inner vertical 1. Clypeus with four setae. Tentorium 55â€“72, 66 Î¼m long, 5â€“7, 6 Î¼m wide. Palpomere lengths (in Î¼m): 10â€“12, 11; 14â€“19, 16; 26â€“29, 28; 43â€“48, 47; 88â€“96, 92. L: 5th/3rd : 3.26â€“3.55, 3.43
Wing (Fig. 1). Anal lobe reduced. VR 1.12â€“1.21, 1.17. Costal extension 40 Î¼m long. Brachiolum with one seta. All veins bare. Squama bare.
Thorax (Fig. 3). Antepronotal lobes developed. Antepronotum with one lateral seta. Dorsocentrals 2â€“4, 3; one prealars. Scutellum with 2â€“6, 5 setae. Mesonotum with a tuft of hairs.

Legs. Spur of fore tibia 24â€“25, 24 Î¼m long; spurs of mid tibia 9â€“12, 11 Î¼m and 12â€“14, 13 Î¼m long; spurs of hind tibia 9â€“10, 9 Î¼m and 20â€“22, 21 Î¼m long. Hind tibial comb with 9â€“12, 11 spines, 19â€“38, 30 Î¼m long. Width at apex of fore tibia 17â€“19, 19 mm, of mid tibia 19â€“20, 19 mm, of hind tibia 21â€“24, 23 mm. Lengths (in Î¼m) and proportions of legs as in Table 1.

caption.p: Lengths (in Î¼m) and proportions of legs of Parakiefferiella fasciata Liu & Wang, sp. n. (n = 4)

tp:treatment-sec.p: Hypopygium (Figs 5â€“7). Anal point triangular and hyaline, very broad at base, with rounded apex and without basal seta. Laterosernite IX with 2â€“4, 3 setae. Phallapodeme 20â€“24, 23 Î¼m long. Transverse sternapodeme 48â€“54, 53 Î¼m long. Virga consisting of four spines, 20 â€“35, 25 Î¼m long. Tergites III and VIII bearing colored bands. Gonocoxite 72â€“74, 73 Î¼m long, outer margins concave medially. Superior volsella absent; inferior volsella rounded and very large, occupying nearly half of the total length of gonocoxite, lacking dorsal setae and densely covered with microtrichia (Fig. 6); ventral margin strongly swollen medially. Gonostylus 36â€“38, 37 Î¼m long, anterior margin nearly straight, posterior margin slightly curved in dorsal view. Megaseta 5â€“7, 7 Î¼m long. Crista dorsalis reduced, slightly visible in lateral view. HR 1.98â€“2.06, 2.01. HV 2.65â€“3.00, 2.75.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Etymology.
tp:treatment-sec.p: The specific name is from Latin fasciata, referring to different colored bands in its tergites.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Remarks.
tp:treatment-sec.p: The new described species is distinguished from all other Parakiefferiella species by the following unusual combination of characters: antenna with ten flagellomeres; tergites III and VIII with colored bands; anal point lacking both dorsal setae and keel; absence of dorsal setae on inferior volsella, which is bearing only microtrichia.

While the new species close related to Parakiefferiella coronata (Edwards, 1929; Makarchenko and Makarchenko 2010). However, the new species differs from the latter on the basis of following characters: (1) the antenna of the new species with ten flagellomeres, whereas Parakiefferiella coronata has 13 flagellomeres; (2) the superior volsella of Parakiefferiella coronata is large, whereas in the new species it is absent; (3) the new species has abdomen pale yellow with tergites III-VIII dark brown, whereas Parakiefferiella coronata has abdomen dark with tergites IV, VI-VII shiny.
Female and immature stages unknown.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Type material.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Holotype: â™‚ (BDN. No.1168), China, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, Liupan Mountain, Erlong river, 35Â°38'40"N, 106Â°31'40"E, 6.viii.1987, sweeping method, Wang XH. Paratypes: 4 â™‚â™‚, as holotype.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
tp:treatment-sec.p: The adult male can be distinguished from known species of the genus by the following combination of characters: anal point obtuse triangular with pointed and hyaline apex, lacking keel and bearing four setae placed laterally (two on each side); antenna with ten flagellomeres; all of the veins bare; inferior volsella square with rounded inner margin, not projected, occupying about half of the gonocoxite length, lacking dorsal setae and covered with microtrichia; ventral margin swollen medially; AR 0.33â€“0.37; HR 2.20â€“2.28; HV 2.36â€“2.43.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Description.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Male imago (n = 5). Total length 1.20â€“1.25, 1.23 mm. Wing length 0.78â€“0.85, 0.81 mm. Total length/wing length 1.45â€“1.47, 1.46. Wing length/length of profemur 3.38â€“3.58, 3.45.
Coloration of preserved specimens. Head and tergites brown. Thorax brown with dark spot.

Head. Antenna (Fig. 9) with ten flagellomeres. AR 0.33â€“0.37. Ultimate flagellomere 108â€“115, 112 Î¼m long. Temporal seta one, including one outer vertical. Clypeus with 3â€“4 setae. Tentorium 62â€“72, 69 Î¼m long, 7â€“9, 8 Î¼m wide. Palpomere lengths (in Î¼m): 12â€“14, 13; 24â€“26, 25; 28â€“34, 31; 28â€“36,32; 52â€“54, 53. L: 5th/3rd : 1.61â€“1.83, 1.81.
Wing (Fig. 8). Anal lobe moderate reduced. VR 1.02â€“1.18, 1.14. Costal extension 40 Î¼m long. Brachiolum with one seta. All of the veins bare. Squama bare.

caption.p: Parakiefferiella liupanensis Liu & Wang, sp. n., male. 8 wing 9 antenna 10 thorax 11 hypopygium (dorsal view) 12 inferior 13 hypopygium (ventral view).

tp:treatment-sec.p: Thorax (Fig. 10). Antepronotal lobes developed. Antepronotum with one lateral seta. Dorsocentrals 5â€“7, 6; acrostichals absent; two prealars. Scutellum with four setae. Mesonotum with a tuft of hairs.

Legs. Spur of fore tibia 12â€“21, 18 Î¼m long; spurs of mid tibia 9â€“12, 11 Î¼m and 12â€“14, 13 Î¼m long; spurs of hind tibia 9â€“10, 9 Î¼m and 20â€“22, 21 Î¼m long. Hind tibial comb with 9â€“12, 10 spines, 19â€“38, 23 Î¼m long. Width at apex of fore tibia 19â€“22, 20 mm, of mid tibia 12â€“22, 17 mm, of hind tibia 18â€“22, 21 mm. Lengths (in Î¼m) and proportions of legs as in Table 2.

caption.p: Lengths (in Î¼m) and proportions of legs of Parakiefferiella liupanensis Liu & Wang, sp. n. (n = 5).

tp:treatment-sec.p: Hypopygium (Figs 11â€“13). Anal point obtuse triangular with pointed and hyaline apex, lacking keel and bearing 4 setae placed laterally (2 on each side). Laterosernite IX with 2â€“4, 3 setae. Phallapodeme 19â€“21, 20 Î¼m long. Transverse sternapodeme, straight 44â€“48, 46 Î¼m long. Virga consisting of two spines, 20 â€“25, 23 Î¼m long. Gonocoxite 79â€“82, 80 Î¼m long. Superior volsella absent; inferior volsella square, occupying about half of the gonocoxite length, lacking dorsal setae and covered with microtrichia (Fig. 12); ventral margin swollen medially. Gonostylus 36â€“38, 37 Î¼m long, narrowed apically, distinctly bent and curved inward in dorsal view; crista dorsal absent. Megaseta 5â€“7, 7 Î¼m long. Without crista dorsalis. HR 2.20â€“2.28, 2.23. HV 2.36â€“2.43, 2.41.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Etymology.
tp:treatment-sec.p: The specific name refers to the Liupan Mountain where the species was collected.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Remarks.
tp:treatment-sec.p: The new species can easily be separated from other related Parakiefferiella species by the following characters: antenna with 10 segments; anal point square, lacking keel and bearing four setae laterally; inferior volsella without dorsal setae and covered with microtrichia.

Parakiefferiella liupanensis Liu & Wang, sp. n. is closely related to Parakiefferiella bathophila (Kiffer, 1912). However, the new species differs from the latter on the basis of the following characters: (1) the antenna of the new species with ten flagellomeres, whereas Parakiefferiella bathophila possesses 13 flagellomeres; (2) the hypopygium of Parakiefferiella bathophila with triangular superior volsella, whereas in the new species it is absent; (3) the anal point of the new species obtuse triangular, not tapered apically, whereas Parakiefferiella bathophila gradually tapered to apex; (4) the shape of inferior volsella in the new species square, without dorsal setae, whereas Parakiefferiella bathophila triangular, with dorsal setae.
Female and immature stages unknown.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Specimens examined.
tp:treatment-sec.p: 1 â™‚, Liaoning Province, Dandong City, Fengcheng County, 40Â°51'00"N, 124Â°07'00"E, 25.iv. 1992, Sweeping net, Wang JC.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Diagnostic characters.
tp:treatment-sec.p: Total length 2.06â€“2.29 mm. Wing length 1.02â€“1.37 mm. AR 0.38â€“0.53. Anal lobe reduced. Laterosernite IX with five setae. Phallapodeme 36â€“38 Î¼m long. Transverse sternapodeme 74â€“81 Î¼m long. Anal point small, triangular and with pointed apex, bare and hyaline excepting the basal portion with microtrichia. Inferior volsella semicircular, bearing dorsal setae. Gonostylus 6 Î¼m long, narrowed apically, distinctly bent and curved inward in dorsal view. Megaseta 10 Î¼m long. HR 2.18. HV 1.56.

tp:treatment-sec.title: Remarks.
tp:treatment-sec.p: The Chinese specimens mainly agree with the original description by Sasa (1981), but they have higher AR (0.53) than the specimens from Japan (0.38â€“0.48).

tp:treatment-sec.title: Distribution.
tp:treatment-sec.p: China (Palaearctic China: Liaoning Province), Japan.

sec.sec-type: Key to known adult males of the genus Parakiefferiella in China
sec.title: Key to known adult males of the genus Parakiefferiella in China

tr.td: Tergites III and VIII dark brown, others pale yellow; all veins bare

td.bold: Parakiefferiella fasciata Liu & Wang, sp. n.

tr.td: All tergites with a narrow dark band on caudal margin; veins very delicate and colorless
Antenna with 13 flagellomeres; inferior volsella triangular or semicircular, bearing dorsal setae
Antenna with 10 flagellomeres; inferior volsella square lacking dorsal setae

td.bold: Parakiefferiella liupanensis Liu & Wang, sp. n.

tr.td: Anal lobe developed; inferior volsella large, roughly triangular
Anal lobe reduced; inferior volsella semicircular
